13B.answer: Ryan Graves describes his experience as an F-18 pilot with the Navy and how he encountered unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP) during a training mission near Virginia Beach. He also mentions that other commercial pilots have confided their similar encounters with him, highlighting the need for action due to underreported cases and excessive classification practices.

13B-Detail.answer:
Ryan Graves, an ex-Navy pilot, testifies about his experience with unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP). He states that these encounters are not rare or isolated events; rather, they occur frequently among military aircrew and commercial pilots who have trained observation skills essential for their professions. The stigma attached to reporting such incidents is real and powerful, which discourages witnesses from coming forward. Additionally, excessive classification practices keep crucial information hidden, fueling speculation and mistrust.

Graves shares his own encounter during a training mission off the coast of Virginia Beach when two F18 Super Hornets were split by UAP. The object described as a dark gray or black cube inside a clear sphere came within 50 feet of one aircraft and was estimated to be 5 to 15 feet in diameter. Despite submitting a safety report, there was no official acknowledgment nor further mechanism provided to report similar sightings.

He and his wingman were participating in air-to-air training when they received real-world tasking to investigate unidentified objects that had been observed for over two weeks. As they approached the location, they noticed whitewater on their right side and a small solid white tic-tac object moving rapidly over the water like a ping-pong ball. The object displayed no rotors, wings, or visible control surfaces. When they started clockwise towards the object, it suddenly shifted its longitudinal axis, aligned itself with my aircraft, and began to climb. They continued down another 270 degrees, nose-low, but by then the tic-tac was gone. Their altitude at this point was around 15,000 feet, and the tic-tac's altitude was approximately 12,000 feet.

13B.answer: ​David Fravor, a former US Navy pilot, describes his experience encountering an unidentified aerial phenomenon (UAP) during a training mission off the coast of San Diego in 2004. He was accompanied by another aircraft and their wingmen, but when they approached the object, it rapidly accelerated in front of them and disappeared within seconds. The radar tape showing active jamming from the object has never been released, and none of the crew members were ever questioned about the incident. It wasn't until 2017 that articles published in the New York Times removed the stigma around discussing UFOs, leading to increased interest from elected officials who want to know where these craft come from, what technology they possess, and how they operate. However, there is no oversight for work done using taxpayer funds on craft believed not to be from Earth.

13B-Detail.answer:
Lt. Ryan Graves begins by introducing himself as an F/A-18 Super Hornet pilot with over 3,500 hours of flight experience. He served in the US Navy for nine years before retiring in 2017. During his service, he was stationed at NAS Lemoore, CA, where he flew with VFA-106 "Gladiators" from 2004 to 2009.

He then describes an incident that occurred during one of their training missions near San Diego, California, involving a Tic Tac-shaped object moving at high speed and performing maneuvers far beyond what any known aircraft could do. The object rapidly accelerated in front of them and disappeared within seconds. This event lasted around half a mile but left no physical evidence behind.

Lt. Graves mentions that they immediately turned back to see where the whitewater (the ocean's surface) was located after losing contact with it, only to find out that it had also vanished along with the mysterious object. They returned to base and shared their encounter with other pilots who were getting ready to launch, including Alex Detrick - another witness present today.

After returning home, Lt. Graves learned about Jay Stratton through social media connections; Mr. Stratton is part of ATIP program led by Lou Elizondo in Pentagon. In 2009, Lt. Graves received information regarding active jamming on APG-73 radar systems caused by the UAP he encountered earlier. However, this information has never been released publicly or investigated further.

In 2017, when Tom DeLonge formed To The Stars Academy alongside former government officials like Louis Elizondo, Chris Mellon, Steve Justice, Helene Cooper, Rob Blumenthal, and Leslie Kean, Lt. Graves decided to come forward as one of the first military whistleblowers speaking openly about his experience with unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP). This decision came after being approached by both Mr. Elizondo and Tom DeLonge separately.

Since then, more witnesses have come forward sharing similar experiences involving advanced technology not from Earth that defies our current understanding of physics and engineering principles. These testimonies highlight the need for oversight over any work done using taxpayer funds related to these mysterious crafts - even if they are classified under an "unacknowledged wave" program within the US Government.

Finally, Lt. Graves emphasizes the importance of ensuring proper checks and balances in place across all government programs dealing with extraterrestrial life forms or technologies so that elected representatives can adequately serve their constituents' interests while protecting national security concerns at the same time.

According to him, he encountered several instances where he had to take evasive action because of the proximity of these mysterious objects. Despite being trained as an aviation safety officer by the Navy, he felt compelled to come forward and share his story out of duty and responsibility towards his fellow pilots still facing such threats.

He explained that based on Doppser's assessment, only unclassified questions could be answered in open sessions like this one. However, any classified matters would require a closed session at the appropriate level. When asked about commercial pilots reporting sightings of UAPs, he confirmed that they too have seen them but with less range and sensors compared to military aircraft.

He emphasized that this town isn't made up entirely of people like them but rather individuals who keep this issue alive despite criticism and derogatory remarks.
